author: Jeffrey Eugenides
description:
Madeleine Hanna was the dutiful English major who didn't get the memo. While everyone else in the early 1980s was reading Derrida, she was happily absorbed with Jane Austen and George Eliot: purveyors of the marriage plot that lies at the heart of the greatest English novels. Madeleine was the girl who dressed a little too nicely for the taste of her more bohemian friends, the perfect girlfriend whose college love life, despite her good looks, hadn't lived up to expectations.
But now, in the spring of her senior year, Madeleine has enrolled in a semiotics course "to see what all the fuss is about," and, for reasons that have nothing to do with school, life and literature will never be the same. Not after she falls in love with Leonard Morten--charismatic loner, college Darwinist and lost Oregon boy--who is possessed of seemingly inexhaustible energy and introduces her to the ecstasies of immediate experience. And certainly not after Mitchell Grammaticus--devotee of Patti Smith and Thomas Merton--resurfaces in her life, obsessed with the idea that Madeleine is destined to be his mate.
review_text: Probably 3.5 stars. Would have been 4 but for the first part of the book, which builds really slowly and wanders somewhat. The three main characters are well drawn and become very real to the reader, but I couldn't find myself overly caring about any of them, and although it was entertaining while I was reading it, it hasn't stayed with me. It was ultimately about as bland as this review. Great ending though.

title: Chasing Harry Winston
author: Lauren Weisberger
description:
Meet Emmy, Leigh, and Adriana. Best friends since college, each has seen her share of career foils and romantic foibles over the past decade. Now, as they approach thirty, they're looking toward their future...and they're not quite sure they like what they see.
When they are each alone on Valentine's Day, the trio makes a pact. Within one year, each woman will change the thing that most challenges her. For Emmy, it will be to find romance--or a fling--in every foreign country she visits. For Leigh, a book editor with a dream boyfriend and dream apartment, no change seems necessary--until she starts to notice a brilliant and brooding man named Jesse. And for commitment-phobic, drop-dead-gorgeous Adriana, her goal is to have an engagement ring and a house in Scarsdale. Each woman starts the year with the best of intentions--which is exactly why the pact goes immediately, and exceptionally, awry.
Filled with delicious insider details, Chasing Harry Winstonwhisks readers into the heart of an elite world, and showcases Weisberger's best storytelling efforts to date.
review_text:
Can definitely tell this book was written by the author of Devil Wears Prada: the book has the same upbeat feel to it and it's very consistent. The book has strong female characters that any group of girlfriends can relate to, much like Sex and the City's famous foursome. This book not only inspires young women to become accomplished but to also enjoy life. 
 I love Adriana's sense of humor and her cockiness!! Definitely my favorite chapters/sections to read!!

title: The Magicians
author: Lev Grossman
description: A thrilling and original coming-of- age novel about a young man practicing magic in the real worldQuentin Coldwater is brilliant but miserable. A senior in high school, he's still secretly preoccupied with a series of fantasy novels he read as a child, set in a magical land called Fillory. Imagine his surprise when he finds himself unexpectedly admitted to a very secret, very exclusive college of magic in upstate New York, where he receives a thorough and rigorous education in the craft of modern sorcery.He also discovers all the other things people learn in college: friendship, love, sex, booze, and boredom. Something is missing, though. Magic doesn't bring Quentin the happiness and adventure he dreamed it would. After graduation he and his friends make a stunning discovery: Fillory is real. But the land of Quentin's fantasies turns out to be much darker and more dangerous than he could have imagined. His childhood dream becomes a nightmare with a shocking truth at its heart.At once psychologically piercing and magnificently absorbing, The Magicians boldly moves into uncharted literary territory, imagining magic as practiced by real people, with their capricious desires and volatile emotions. review_text:
I'm torn, I finished it, which all told means I didn't think it was that bad. That said I'm not looking to go back and read it again right away, or ever for that matter. 
 The main character was not that interesting to me. I'm not big on whiners, I have a 9 year old boy in the house I don't need to read about them I live it, and I felt like he was a big whiner. 
 Not entirely true it didn't feel that bad in the first part of the book (aka Book 1) but once he left school, well blah. He had a bit in the middle that I felt like he might redeem himself, but not so much. 
 Then the ending left me annoyed, I kept thinking if he doesn't bring back Julia at some point I'm gonna be pissed, why have the character, then he does but in the last few paragraphs. I don't care enough about any of them to read the next book in the series. So I'm back to why even introduce her. 
 Overall meh.

title: Everyone Worth Knowing
author: Lauren Weisberger
description:
What happens when a girl on the fringe enters the realm of New York's chic, party-hopping elite?
Soon after Bette Robinson quits her horrendous Manhattan banking job like the impulsive girl she's never been, the novelty of walking her four-pound dog around the unglamorous Murray Hill neighborhood wears as thin as the "What are you going to do with your life?" phone calls from her parents. Then Bette meets Kelly, head of Manhattan's hottest PR firm, and suddenly she has a brand-new job where the primary requirement is to see and be seen inside the VIP rooms of the city's most exclusive nightclubs. But when Bette begins appearing in a vicious new gossip column, she realizes that the line between her personal life and her professional life is...invisible.
review_text: Love this book, especially the author!

title: Go Set A Watchman
author: Harper Lee
description: From Harper Lee comes a landmark new novel set two decades after her beloved Pulitzer Prize-winning masterpiece, To Kill a Mockingbird. Maycomb, Alabama. Twenty-six-year-old Jean Louise Finch--"Scout"--returns home from New York City to visit her aging father, Atticus. Set against the backdrop of the civil rights tensions and political turmoil that were transforming the South, Jean Louise's homecoming turns bittersweet when she learns disturbing truths about her close-knit family, the town and the people dearest to her. Memories from her childhood flood back, and her values and assumptions are thrown into doubt. Featuring many of the iconic characters from To Kill a Mockingbird, Go Set a Watchmanperfectly captures a young woman, and a world, in a painful yet necessary transition out of the illusions of the past--a journey that can be guided only by one's conscience. Written in the mid-1950s, Go Set a Watchmanimparts a fuller, richer understanding and appreciation of Harper Lee. Here is an unforgettable novel of wisdom, humanity, passion, humor and effortless precision--a profoundly affecting work of art that is both wonderfully evocative of another era and relevant to our own times. It not only confirms the enduring brilliance of To Kill a Mockingbird, but also serves as its essential companion, adding depth, context and new meaning to an American classic.
review_text: this book was just awful. when did Scout become such a shallow, pathetic character. thank goodness this was not the first book published or the world would have missed to kill a mockingbird.

title: Death Comes To Pemberley
author: P. D. James
description:
The world is classic Jane Austen. The mystery is vintage P.D. James.
The year is 1803, and Fitzwilliam Darcy and Elizabeth Bennet have been married for six years. There are now two handsome and healthy sons in the nursery, Elizabeth's beloved sister Jane and her husband Bingley live nearby and the orderly world of Pemberley seems unassailable. But all this is threatened when, on the eve of the annual autumn ball, the guests are preparing to retire for the night when a chaise appears, rocking down the path from Pemberley's wild woodland. As it pulls up, Lydia Wickham - Elizabeth Bennet's younger, unreliable sister - stumbles out screaming that her husband has been murdered.
Two great literary minds - master of suspense P.D. James and literary icon Jane Austen - come together in Death Comes to Pemberley, a bestselling historical crime fiction tribute to Pride and Prejudice. Conjuring the world of Elizabeth Bennet and Mark Darcy and combining the trappings of Regency British society with a classic murder mystery, James creates a delightful mash-up that will intrigue any Janeite.
From the bestselling author of The Murder Room, Children of Men and A Certain Justice, comes a wonderful mixture of the nation's greatest romance and best-loved crime fiction. In 2013, this novel was adapted as a miniseries by the BBC, starring Matthew Rhys as Darcy, Anna Maxwell Martin as Elizabeth Bennet and Jenna Coleman as Lydia Wickham.
review_text: Very meh. There was a lot of telling and very little showing. Also, a lot of repetition, unnecessary rehashings of the P&P plot, and the characters felt more like bare outlines than fully-fleshed characters.

title: Go Set A Watchman
author: Harper Lee
description: From Harper Lee comes a landmark new novel set two decades after her beloved Pulitzer Prize-winning masterpiece, To Kill a Mockingbird. Maycomb, Alabama. Twenty-six-year-old Jean Louise Finch--"Scout"--returns home from New York City to visit her aging father, Atticus. Here is an unforgettable novel of wisdom, humanity, passion, humor and effortless precision--a profoundly affecting work of art that is both wonderfully evocative of another era and relevant to our own times. It not only confirms the enduring brilliance of To Kill a Mockingbird, but also serves as its essential companion, adding depth, context and new meaning to an American classic.
review_text:
Going into the reading of "Go Set A Watchman" I had told myself that I was going to approach this novel as if I had never read "To Kill A Mockingbird" at all. I wanted to give it my fair and undivided attention, and I'm glad I took this approach. 
 So, what did I think after finishing the book? I liked it - mostly. 
 The first half of the book is just a delightful collection of short stories about Jean Louise Finch's life growing up in the Deep South. I loved learning more about "Scout's" family - Aunty Alexandra and Uncle Dr. Jack Finch, and I particularly loved the vignette that found their church music director in a quandary on how to present hymn correctly - Jean Louise and Uncle Jack soon helped him puzzle out that problem and get back on the right track! Just a charming tale! 
 And then after chapter 8, things begin to go downhill. There has been much talk about how disappointed people were in the fact that Lee presents Atticus Finch in a very different light than in TKAM - but I found him a very "human" character that was just adapting to the times of the day that he lived in. 
 All in all - I love Harper Lee's style of writing - you can almost taste the sawmill gravy smothering the biscuits and smell the perfume of the cape jessamine in the air through her words and for that reason alone should stand the high recommendation to read this novel. It is a work of wonderful Southern fiction that, I'm afraid, will be well known for it's controversy than for it's beautiful writing. I, for one, will treasure it alongside my copy of "To Kill A Mockingbird" regardless of what others might say.

title: The Mermaid Chair
author: Sue Monk Kidd
description:
An alternate cover edition exists .
Sue Monk Kidd's phenomenal debut, The Secret Life of Bees, became a runaway bestseller that is still on the New York Timesbestseller list more than two years after its paperback publication. Now, in her luminous new novel, Kidd has woven a transcendent tale that will thrill her legion of fans. Telling the story of Jessie Sullivan -- a love story between a woman and a monk, a woman and her husband, and ultimately a woman and her own soul -- Kidd charts a journey of awakening and self-discovery illuminated with a brilliance that only a writer of her ability could conjure.
review_text: Nice easy read!

author: Harper Lee

review_text:
** spoiler alert ** 
 I give this 3.5 stars. I don't really know where to start..I feel a huge letdown because To Kill a Mockingbird was such an influential and classical book and this one was just not. It was hard for me to finish it, but I am not sure why she chose to publish this. I was definitely disappointed in Atticus' character and how he evolved. However, I am still deciding whether Atticus was valid in his point or if Scout was right. The book left me wondering a lot of things..which could mean that this book served its purpose and is brilliant. All I know is I wouldn't go out of your way to read it.

title: The Tenth Circle
author: Jodi Picoult
description: Fourteen-year-old Trixie Stone is in love for the first time. She's also the light of her father, Daniel's life -- a straight-A student; a pretty, popular freshman in high school; a girl who's always seen her father as a hero. That is, until her world is turned upside down with a single act of violence. Suddenly everything Trixie has believed about her family -- and herself -- seems to be a lie. Could the boyfriend who once made Trixie wild with happiness have been the one to end her childhood forever? She says that he is, and that is all it takes to make Daniel, a seemingly mild-mannered comic book artist with a secret tumultuous past he has hidden even from his family, venture to hell and back to protect his daughter. With The Tenth Circle, Jodi Picoult offers her most powerful chronicle yet as she explores the unbreakable bond between parent and child, and questions whether you can reinvent yourself in the course of a lifetime -- or if your mistakes are carried forever.
review_text: I usually love Jodi's novels, but unfortunately I had to deduct a few stars for this one. I found the comic/graphic illustrations (created by Trixie's father) to be impressive, but frankly the dialogue used in them was pretty average! I had trouble believing he was a professional comic artist based on these. I skipped over most of them. Secondly, why was this novel not centred on the actual rape and the circumstances around it? There were some rather deep issues presented here, such as Trixie 'cutting' and the use of date rape drugs, which I felt were dropped into the novel for dramatic effect, but then skirted around when the novel took an entirely different direction. I would normally expect Jodi to delve into some of these issues further in the courtroom, and frankly feel a little duped that this wasn't the case in this novel :-(

review_text: I wish the places talked about in this book were real! I loved this book.

title: A Spool Of Blue Thread
author: Anne Tyler
description:
'It was a beautiful, breezy, yellow-and-green afternoon...'
This is the way Abby Whitshank always begins the story of how she and Red fell in love that day in July 1959. The whole family on the porch, relaxed, half-listening as their mother tells the same tale they have heard so many times before.
And yet this gathering is different. Abby and Red are getting older, and decisions must be made about how best to look after them and their beloved family home. They've all come, even Denny, who can usually be relied on only to please himself.
From that porch we spool back through three generations of the Whitshanks, witnessing the events, secrets and unguarded moments that have come to define who and what they are. And while all families like to believe they are special, round that kitchen table over all those years we see played out the hopes and fears, the rivalries and tensions of families everywhere - the essential nature of family life.
review_text: I stayed with this book, and I'm glad that I did. About halfway through, it really picks up and becomes interesting. That's not to say that the beginning of it was a drag. I'd describe it as being very expository. There were distinct scenes, but Tyler did way more telling than showing in the first part of the book. What is there to expect when one writes a story where the house is the protagonist? It's not like we exit realism to have the staircase opening up to speak or the windows blinking their shutters open and closed, like eyelids. Instead we are given histories of ordinary people who fall in and out of love with this house and with each other. The house bares witness to it all. Of course this novel is set in Baltimore as are all of Tyler's novels. Being from South Carolina, it's nice to read about the change of seasons since we get mild, short versions of fall and winter, here. I feel like a real writer when I read Anne Tyler because I can tell that character is the medium in her work. I feel like she watched people and recorded their activities. If I ever visit Baltimore again, I feel as if I could bump into some of the characters, but I'd settle for bumping into Tyler.

title: The Girls
author: Emma Cline
description: Northern California, during the violent end of the 1960s. At the start of summer, a lonely and thoughtful teenager, Evie Boyd, sees a group of girls in the park, and is immediately caught by their freedom, their careless dress, their dangerous aura of abandon. Soon, Evie is in thrall to Suzanne, a mesmerizing older girl, and is drawn into the circle of a soon-to-be infamous cult and the man who is its charismatic leader. Hidden in the hills, their sprawling ranch is eerie and run down, but to Evie, it is exotic, thrilling, charged--a place where she feels desperate to be accepted. As she spends more time away from her mother and the rhythms of her daily life, and as her obsession with Suzanne intensifies, Evie does not realize she is coming closer and closer to unthinkable violence, and to that moment in a girl's life when everything can go horribly wrong.
review_text:
One of those books that hooks you from page one. Incredibly well-written, with a linguistic spectrum that is at once broad and inventive as well as keeping within its own framework, resulting in a language of its own where each word is as significant as the other. 
 The last page leaves you with a punch in the stomach, and this book took my breath away. Believe the hype.

title: Beowulf
author: translated by Seamus Heaney
description:
Song of the Battle and Kings
Beowulfis the earliest extant poem in a modern European language. It was composed in England four centuries before the Norman Conquest. As a social document this great epic poem is invaluable- reflecting a feudal, newly Christian world of heroes and monsters, blood and victory, life and death. As a work of art it is quite unique; Beowulfrings with a beaut, power, and artistry that have kept it alive for more than twelve centuries. The noble simplicity of Beowulf's anonymous Anglo-Saxon singer is recaptured in this vivid translation by Burton Raffel.
review_text: What a great read! I'm a sucker for high fantasy so this was right up my alley. It felt like I was reading Tolkien, except this work precedes his by roughly a thousand years, so maybe Tolkein felt like Beowulf. Anyways, the language is beautiful (I read the Burton translation) and the narrative is super engaging. Old tales usually try to convey a message of wisdom and although I haven't analysed this book academically (yet!) I would say the poem seems to point in the direction of questioning the pursuit of power and how power transforms people. With Christian allusions and sacrifice all over the place, I feel pretty confident in my analysis. Maybe I'm totally off but that's what I took from it. Outstanding read 5/5!

title: Death Comes To Pemberley
author: P. D. James
description: En sus seis anos de matrimonio, Elizabeth y Darcy han forjado una vida tranquila y feliz para su familia en Pemberley, la impresionante propiedad de Darcy. Su padre es un visitante regular; Su hermana Jane y su marido, Bingley, viven cerca; Las perspectivas de matrimonio para la hermana de Darcy, Georgiana, son favorables. Y los preparativos para su baile anual de otono estan avanzando a buen ritmo. Pero en la vispera del baile, el caos desciende. Lydia Wickham, la desgraciada hermana de Elizabeth que, con su esposo, ha sido excluida de la finca, llega en un estado histerico gritando que Wickham ha sido asesinado. Sumergido en un misterio espantoso y en un juicio de asesinato espeluznante, las vidas de los duenos y criados de Pemberley por igual, no seran nunca las mismas.
review_text: Pointless. This book was so long and boring to get through. I have never read a book with such repetition. First it reviews Pride and Prejudice (I'm not sure who would read this book or understand all it's intricacies if they hadn't, so this is simply annoying- PD James is no Jane Austin), then it tells the same story over and over and over and over - and what is worse, it was a boring story in the first place. Then finally, there is one section, again repetitive, though not as bad- that explains everything. Granted, this is slightly more logical and interesting than the previous 145 pages, but it then seeks to plug holes in the P&P story that didn't really need plugging. Finally, the book is ended with another rewriting of Pride and Prejudice. I feel that this was fan fiction that may have been fun to write, but should never have been published. The last thing that made this book even worse was that PD James had obviously researched the law of the time (or if it's made up, it's insanely boring and annoying additional information) and seems to have included it to prove that the research had been done. I apologise to the girls in my book club who also had to read this.

title: The TigerS Wife
author: Tea Obreht
description:
Weaving a brilliant latticework of family legend, loss, and love, Tea Obreht, the youngest of The New Yorker's twenty best American fiction writers under forty, has spun a timeless novel that will establish her as one of the most vibrant, original authors of her generation.
In a Balkan country mending from years of conflict, Natalia, a young doctor, arrives on a mission of mercy at an orphanage by the sea. By the time she and her lifelong friend Zora begin to inoculate the children there, she feels age-old superstitions and secrets gathering everywhere around her. Secrets her outwardly cheerful hosts have chosen not to tell her. Secrets involving the strange family digging for something in the surrounding vineyards. Secrets hidden in the landscape itself.
But Natalia is also confronting a private, hurtful mystery of her own: the inexplicable circumstances surrounding her beloved grandfather's recent death. After telling her grandmother that he was on his way to meet Natalia, he instead set off for a ramshackle settlement none of their family had ever heard of and died there alone. A famed physician, her grandfather must have known that he was too ill to travel. Why he left home becomes a riddle Natalia is compelled to unravel.
Grief struck and searching for clues to her grandfather's final state of mind, she turns to the stories he told her when she was a child. On their weeklytrips to the zoo he would read to her from a worn copy of Rudyard Kipling's The Jungle Book, which he carried with him everywhere; later, he told her stories of his own encounters over many years with "the deathless man," a vagabond who claimed to be immortal and appeared never to age. But the most extraordinary story of all is the one her grandfather never told her, the one Natalia must discover for herself. One winter during the Second World War, his childhood village was snowbound, cut off even from the encroaching German invaders but haunted by another, fierce presence: a tiger who comes ever closer under cover of darkness. "These stories," Natalia comes to understand, "run like secret rivers through all the other stories" of her grandfather's life. And it is ultimately within these rich, luminous narratives that she will find the answer she is looking for.
review_text: I can't believe Obreht was 26 when this book was published. Her writing style is so incredibly lyrical, incredibly beautiful, and I hope she's going to publish lots of lots of books. (Pretty pleaseee!) The last few pages were so beautifully written I almost cried. Holy crap.

title: A Spool Of Blue Thread
author: Anne Tyler
description:
A freshly observed, joyful and wrenching, funny and true new novel from Anne Tyler
"It was a beautiful, breezy, yellow-and-green afternoon." This is how Abby Whitshank always begins the story of how she fell in love with Red that day in July 1959. The Whitshanks are one of those families that radiate togetherness: an indefinable, enviable kind of specialness. But they are also like all families, in that the stories they tell themselves reveal only part of the picture. Abby and Red and their four grown children have accumulated not only tender moments, laughter, and celebrations, but also jealousies, disappointments, and carefully guarded secrets. from Red's father and mother, newly-arrived in Baltimore in the 1920s, to Abby and Red's grandchildren carrying the family legacy boisterously into the twenty-first century, here are four generations of Whitshanks, their lives unfolding in and around the sprawling, lovingly worn Baltimore house that has always been their anchor.
Brimming with all the insight, humour, and generosity of spirit that are the hallmarks of Anne Tyler's work, A Spool of Blue Threadtells a poignant yet unsentimental story in praise of family in all its emotional complexity. It is a novel to cherish.
review_text: The first half is slow--keep reading. You won't regret it.

title: The Marriage Plot
author: Jeffrey Eugenides
description:
A New York TimesNotable Book of 2011
A Publisher's WeeklyTop 10 Book of 2011
A Kirkus ReviewsTop 25 Best Fiction of 2011 Title
One of Library Journal's Best Books of 2011
A SalonBest Fiction of 2011 title
One of TheTelegraph's Best Fiction Books of the Year 2011
It's the early 1980s--the country is in a deep recession, and life after college is harder than ever. In the cafes on College Hill, the wised-up kids are inhaling Derrida and listening to Talking Heads. But Madeleine Hanna, dutiful English major, is writing her senior thesis on Jane Austen and George Eliot, purveyors of the marriage plot that lies at the heart of the greatest English novels.
As Madeleine tries to understand why "it became laughable to read writers like Cheever and Updike, who wrote about the suburbia Madeleine and most of her friends had grown up in, in favor of reading the Marquis de Sade, who wrote about deflowering virgins in eighteenth-century France," real life, in the form of two very different guys, intervenes. Leonard Bankhead--charismatic loner, college Darwinist, and lost Portland boy--suddenly turns up in a semiotics seminar, and soon Madeleine finds herself in a highly charged erotic and intellectual relationship with him. At the same time, her old "friend" Mitchell Grammaticus--who's been reading Christian mysticism and generally acting strange--resurfaces, obsessed with the idea that Madeleine is destined to be his mate.
Over the next year, as the members of the triangle in this amazing, spellbinding novel graduate from college and enter the real world, events force them to reevaluate everything they learned in school. Leonard and Madeleine move to a biology Laboratory on Cape Cod, but can't escape the secret responsible for Leonard's seemingly inexhaustible energy and plunging moods. And Mitchell, traveling around the world to get Madeleine out of his mind, finds himself face-to-face with ultimate questions about the meaning of life, the existence of God, and the true nature of love.
Are the great love stories of the nineteenth century dead? Or can there be a new story, written for today and alive to the realities of feminism, sexual freedom, prenups, and divorce? With devastating wit and an abiding understanding of and affection for his characters, Jeffrey Eugenides revives the motivating energies of the Novel, while creating a story so contemporary and fresh that it reads like the intimate journal of our own lives.
review_text: This one felt sort of epic, if not a little pretentious. Nevertheless, it stuck with me for days afterwards. The characters are authentic and enthralling. The Marriage Plot is thoughtful and highly entertaining.

title: The Circle
author: Dave Eggers
description:
When Mae Holland is hired to work for the Circle, the world's most powerful internet company, she feels she's been given the opportunity of a lifetime. The Circle, run out of a sprawling California campus, links users' personal emails, social media, banking, and purchasing with their universal operating system, resulting in one online identity and a new age of civility and transparency.
As Mae tours the open-plan office spaces, the towering glass dining facilities, the cozy dorms for those who spend nights at work, she is thrilled with the company's modernity and activity. There are parties that last through the night, there are famous musicians playing on the lawn, there are athletic activities and clubs and brunches, and even an aquarium of rare fish retrieved from the Marianas Trench by the CEO.
Mae can't believe her luck, her great fortune to work for the most influential company in America - even as life beyond the campus grows distant, even as a strange encounter with a colleague leaves her shaken, even as her role at the Circle becomes increasingly public. What begins as the captivating story of one woman's ambition and idealism soon becomes a heart-racing novel of suspense, raising questions about memory, history, privacy, democracy, and the limits of human knowledge.
review_text: Very funny and thought provoking.

author: Anne Tyler
description:

review_text: I don't know why I have gone so long without reading something by Anne Tyler! This was absolutely lovely, a long meandering visit with a host of characters- complex, and flawed, and lovable. She tells the story of a family, messy and complicated and full of life and laughter and exasperation. Every bit of it rang true as a bell.

review_text:
It took me longer than I expected to get through this audiobook, in part because I made the mistake of picking another (The Signature of All Things) up from the library halfway through. Because the latter was on a tight deadline, I set aside The Marriage Plot for a little while. It might have been the inconsistent nature of my listening, but I didn't connect to this novel as much as I expected to. 
 Read my full review here: http://www.thewhynottblog.com/audiobo...

review_text: This is very beautifully written, almost like a collection of short stories told with the framework of Natalia learning about her grandfather's death. I would take away half a star simply because the narrative strayed so far from the original plotline near the end, focusing on characters who were only tangentially related to Natalia, but that is just my preference. It was still very beautiful and impressive for a first novel.

title: Beowulf
author: translated by Seamus Heaney
description:
Composed towards the end of the first millennium, the Anglo-Saxon poem Beowulfis one of the great Northern epics and a classic of European literature. In his new translation, Seamus Heaney has produced a work which is both true, line by line, to the original poem, and an expression, in its language and music, of something fundamental to his own creative gift.
The poem is about encountering the monstrous, defeating it, and then having to live on, physically and psychically exposed, in that exhausted aftermath. It is not hard to draw parallels between this story and the history of the twentieth century, nor can Heaney's Beowulffail to be read partly in the light of his Northern Irish upbringing. But it also transcends such considerations, telling us psychological and spiritual truths that are permanent and liberating.
review_text: The translation I had took a pagan story and added Christianity to it. It felt forced and out of place.

title: The Tenth Circle
author: Jodi Picoult
description: Fourteen-year-old Trixie Stone is in love for the first time. She's also the light of her father, Daniel's life -- a straight-A student; a pretty, popular freshman in high school; a girl who's always seen her father as a hero. That is, until her world is turned upside down with a single act of violence. Suddenly everything Trixie has believed about her family -- and herself -- seems to be a lie. Could the boyfriend who once made Trixie wild with happiness have been the one to end her childhood forever? She says that he is, and that is all it takes to make Daniel, a seemingly mild-mannered comic book artist with a secret tumultuous past he has hidden even from his family, venture to hell and back to protect his daughter. With The Tenth Circle, Jodi Picoult offers her most powerful chronicle yet as she explores the unbreakable bond between parent and child, and questions whether you can reinvent yourself in the course of a lifetime -- or if your mistakes are carried forever.
review_text: A lower-tier Picoult--a bit too dark and braphic, and the comic-book illustrations didn't do a thing for me.

title: The Circle
author: Dave Eggers
description:
When Mae Holland is hired to work for the Circle, the world's most powerful internet company, she feels she's been given the opportunity of a lifetime. The Circle, run out of a sprawling California campus, links users' personal emails, social media, banking, and purchasing with their universal operating system, resulting in one online identity and a new age of civility and transparency.
As Mae tours the open-plan office spaces, the towering glass dining facilities, the cozy dorms for those who spend nights at work, she is thrilled with the company's modernity and activity. There are parties that last through the night, there are famous musicians playing on the lawn, there are athletic activities and clubs and brunches, and even an aquarium of rare fish retrieved from the Marianas Trench by the CEO.
Mae can't believe her luck, her great fortune to work for the most influential company in America - even as life beyond the campus grows distant, even as a strange encounter with a colleague leaves her shaken, even as her role at the Circle becomes increasingly public. What begins as the captivating story of one woman's ambition and idealism soon becomes a heart-racing novel of suspense, raising questions about memory, history, privacy, democracy, and the limits of human knowledge.
review_text:
This futurist novel was very frightening. It speaks of a world where transparency which is the ability for one corporation to know every detail of a person's life would be the norm. The circle is a google type company and the novel starts when Mae, a 20 something girl starts as a customer service rep. 
 Mae soon learns that to work at the Circle, ones entire life must revolve around it: employees are expected to attend its many events, go to its doctors, shop at its stores, join its groups. Mae was recommended for the job by her friend Annie, a higher up who seems the only really likable character in the book. Mae soon becomes enthralled with her new way of life, discarding not only her parents but an old boyfriend and finally Annie in her quest to move forward. 
 The novel is long and describes tons, and I means tons of ways the is company could impinge on human rights, from implanting trackers in infants which will track not only whereabouts, but grades, homework, home many hours they are watching tv, etc for the rest of their life. There is also the idea of people wearing cameras so the entire world can watch what they are doing 24 hours a day. Scary stuff and I felt a chill reading all of it. There is a few issues with the novel-one being overkill 
 Are we supposed to believe one human employee can do her customer service job while also training other employees via screen, update and answer Zings and questions from thousand of people at a time, surf through and answers photos and comments from thousands of interest groups and answer thousand of survey questions all at once? Not possible. 
 There is also no explanation as to why Mae in particular is singled out for her projects or how a company with 10, 000 and more employees has time to call people in to complain about missing a Portugal themed brunch. There is also the idea that all social media is responded to in a positive way with almost no one saying any negative. This is completely contrary to what we know and experience. Where were the trolls? Then there is the idea that millions of people are ok with everyone from their kids to their grandparents watching them have sex, have medical appointments, use the bathroom, shower etc. I simply cannot imagine this at all. 
 I disliked Mae immensely and hated her more as the story went along. The story with Kalden went nowhere and shouldn't even have been included. Scary stuff but went a bit overboard.

title: The Mermaid Chair
author: Sue Monk Kidd
description:
An alternate cover edition exists .
Sue Monk Kidd's phenomenal debut, The Secret Life of Bees, became a runaway bestseller that is still on the New York Timesbestseller list more than two years after its paperback publication. Now, in her luminous new novel, Kidd has woven a transcendent tale that will thrill her legion of fans. Telling the story of Jessie Sullivan -- a love story between a woman and a monk, a woman and her husband, and ultimately a woman and her own soul -- Kidd charts a journey of awakening and self-discovery illuminated with a brilliance that only a writer of her ability could conjure.
review_text: I started this while at the beach. At first I read it just to read something but the more I read the more it pulled me in. Enjoyed the story well enough and the characters were stronger. Not a bad read.

review_text: I read this ages ago, but apparently didn't post a review. Which is kind of fitting as this book is something of a non-entity. I generally like P.D. James a lot, but the Austen characterisation felt off, and nothing very interesting happened in terms of plot. Some nice prose in there, but otherwise, meh.

title: The Circle
author: Dave Eggers
description:
The Circleis the exhilarating new novel from Dave Eggers, best-selling author of A Hologram for the King, a finalist for the National Book Award.

review_text: I think many people should read this, not because of its literary value, but because it terrifyingly too close to reality. The characters are flat and the plot drags but the premise of a totalitarian government knowing everything about everyone because of social media is very close at hand. Too many times in this book did a situation ring true to my life. Scary, but yet plausible.

title: Luckiest Girl Alive
author: Jessica Knoll
description:
HER PERFECT LIFE IS A PERFECT LIE.
As a teenager at the prestigious Bradley School, Ani FaNelli endured a shocking, public humiliation that left her desperate to reinvent herself. Now, with a glamorous job, expensive wardrobe, and handsome blue blood fiance, she's this close to living the perfect life she's worked so hard to achieve.
But Ani has a secret.
There's something else buried in her past that still haunts her, something private and painful that threatens to bubble to the surface and destroy everything.
With a singular voice and twists you won't see coming, Luckiest Girl Alive explores the unbearable pressure that so many women feel to "have it all" and introduces a heroine whose sharp edges and cutthroat ambition have been protecting a scandalous truth, and a heart that's bigger than it first appears.
The question remains: will breaking her silence destroy all that she has worked for--or, will it at long last, set Ani free?
review_text: At 17% I have to give up. I just cant handle this book! The main character is making me angry. I mean if you don't want to get married then why are you. And for the love of God stop Bitching!!!
